newer_release.body:
# Changelog

Changelog for the runtimes governed by the Polkadot Fellowship.

The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/).

## [2.0.5] 13.01.2026

### Added
- Bridge-Hubs - Add proxy pallet ([#1045](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/1045)).
- AH Polkadot - A new stepped curve primitive. Used for the 'Hard Pressure' inflation changes from [Ref 1710](https://polkadot.subsquare.io/referenda/1710) ([#898](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/898)).
- AH Polkadot - Added `pallet_revive` and changed proof size fee formula ([polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/1050](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/1050))
- Add `cumulus-pallet-weight-reclaim` to all Polkadot system parachains (Asset Hub, Bridge Hub, Coretime, People, Collectives) for storage weight reclaim functionality ([#1047](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/1047)).

### Changed

- AH Polkadot - Inflation now follows the 'Hard Pressure' schedule from [Ref 1710](https://polkadot.subsquare.io/referenda/1710) ([#898](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/898))
- AH Polkadot - Enable Elastic Scaling for Polkadot Hub ([polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/1048](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/1048))
- AH Polkadot - Inflation now follows the 'Hard Pressure' schedule from [Ref 1710](https://polkadot.subsquare.io/referenda/1710) ([#898](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/898)).

### Fixed

- [PAH] Migrate missing Stellaswap sovereign accounts ([1036](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/1036))

# Runtime info
*These runtimes were built with **rustc 1.88.0 (6b00bc388 2025-06-23)** using **[srtool v0.18.3](https://github.com/paritytech/srtool)***

To replicate the build, use the following command:
```sh
srtool build
       --root --profile production
       --package CRATE_NAME --runtime-dir PATH_TO_CRATE
       --build-opts=""
```

# Release Analysis: v2.0.4 to v2.0.5 (Polkadot Fellows Runtimes)

## Executive Summary for Non-Technical Users

This release brings several important improvements to the Polkadot ecosystem, focusing on enhanced functionality, better performance, and improved infrastructure.

### Main Improvements:
- **Smart Contract Support Enhanced**: Added advanced smart contract capabilities to Polkadot's Asset Hub, enabling developers to build more sophisticated applications
- **Better Performance**: Improved how the network handles transactions and reduces unnecessary resource usage across all system chains
- **Enhanced Security**: Added proxy functionality to Bridge Hubs, allowing for more secure delegation of permissions
- **Faster Block Processing**: Enabled elastic scaling on Polkadot Hub, preparing it to process blocks faster when additional computing cores become available
- **Updated Economic Model**: Implemented a new "Hard Pressure" inflation model as approved by community governance

### Benefits Users Will See:
- More reliable and efficient transaction processing
- Enhanced smart contract capabilities on Polkadot
- Better resource optimization leading to potentially lower fees
- Improved infrastructure stability

### Actions Required:
- **No immediate action needed** for regular users
- Developers working with smart contracts should review the new Revive pallet capabilities
- Bridge operators may want to explore new proxy features

## Key Changes Explained

### New Features
**Smart Contract Enhancement (Revive Pallet)**
- Added advanced smart contract functionality to Polkadot's Asset Hub
- This allows developers to build more complex decentralized applications
- Includes better integration with existing assets and cross-chain functionality

**Proxy Support for Bridges**
- Bridge Hubs now support proxy accounts, allowing users to delegate specific permissions
- This improves security by enabling limited access without sharing full account control
- Particularly useful for automated bridge operations

### Performance Improvements
**Storage Weight Reclaim**
- Added intelligent resource management across all Polkadot system chains
- The system now reclaims unused storage space, making operations more efficient
- This can lead to lower transaction costs and better network performance

**Elastic Scaling Preparation**
- Polkadot Hub is now configured to use multiple processing cores
- Currently maintains 6-second block times, but ready to achieve 2-second blocks when additional cores are assigned
- This significantly increases the network's transaction processing capacity

### Security Improvements
**Enhanced Access Control**
- New proxy system provides granular permission management
- Improved delegation mechanisms reduce risk of unauthorized access
- Better separation of concerns for different types of operations

### Economic Model Updates
**Hard Pressure Inflation Model**
- Implemented new inflation schedule approved by community referendum
- Uses a stepped curve approach that asymptotically approaches target values
- Provides more predictable and controlled inflation management

## Technical Summary for Developers

### Major API/Interface Changes
- **New Pallet**: `pallet_revive` added to Asset Hub Polkadot with Ethereum Virtual Machine compatibility
- **Proxy Integration**: `pallet_proxy` added to Bridge Hubs with custom proxy types (`NonTransfer`, `CancelProxy`, `Collator`)
- **Weight Reclaim**: `cumulus-pallet-weight-reclaim` integrated across all system parachains
- **Fee Structure**: Modified `WeightToFee` calculations with new proof size formulas

### Migration Requirements
- **Runtime Versions**: All runtime spec versions updated to `2_000_005`
- **Weight Formulas**: Fee calculation changes may affect transaction cost estimations
- **Storage**: Automatic migration for specific Stellaswap accounts on Asset Hub Polkadot
- **Staking Configuration**: Updated validator set export timing for elastic scaling

### Technical Improvements
- **Elastic Scaling Configuration**: Asset Hub Polkadot configured for 3-core processing with 2-second block time targets
- **Buffered Elections**: Implemented buffered validator set exports to handle block time changes gracefully
- **Build Process**: Consolidated dependency installation using `install-deps` infrastructure
- **CI/CD**: Enhanced GitHub Actions with better error handling and Docker-in-Docker support

## Code Impact Analysis

### Most Affected Components
1. **Asset Hub Polkadot** (59 files changed): Major additions with Revive pallet integration and elastic scaling
2. **Bridge Hubs** (10 files changed): Proxy pallet addition with comprehensive access control
3. **System-wide Infrastructure**: Weight reclaim integration across all parachains
4. **Build and CI Systems**: Dependency management and testing infrastructure improvements

### Types of Changes
- **New Features (40%)**: Revive pallet, proxy support, elastic scaling, storage weight reclaim
- **Infrastructure Improvements (30%)**: Build processes, CI/CD enhancements, dependency management
- **Performance Optimizations (20%)**: Weight formulas, resource reclaim, block time improvements
- **Bug Fixes and Migrations (10%)**: Account migrations, workflow fixes, zombienet test improvements

### Key Metrics
- **Total Files Changed**: 159 files across all PRs
- **Code Additions**: ~5,659 lines added
- **Code Deletions**: ~2,551 lines removed
- **Net Growth**: Significant expansion in functionality with ~3,108 net lines added

This release represents a substantial enhancement to the Polkadot ecosystem, with particular focus on smart contract capabilities, performance optimization, and infrastructure robustness.

pr_details.title: GH Runner: Put solc and resolc in tmp directory instead of work dir
pr_details.author: skunert
pr_details.body:
While working on https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/1047 I noticed that the `/cmd bench` command commits `solc` and  `resolc` binaries. This is unwanted.

I propose to not put the binaries into the main repo directory, but use the `RUNNER_TEMP` directory. Then we have a general solution and don't need to mess with manual exclusion of whatever tooling we want in the future in the git workflow.

Example commit created by bot which shows the issue: https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/1047/changes/1854d62f62aca882d57421d9fb3580efd45efd95

Example commit which shows that fix works (no binaries present): https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/1047/changes/a4e34dfcf52447770d5a0ea4ea2cc38c325fd198

- [x] Does not require a CHANGELOG entry

pr_details.title: [AHM] Migrate missing stellaswap account
pr_details.author: ggwpez
pr_details.body:
The Asset Hub migration translated specific account IDs such that they would stay accessible after the migration.  
We missed two such accounts that were generated in a specific recursive manner and are fixing this now.

## Changes

Add an extrinsic `AhOps::translate_para_sovereign_child_to_sibling_derived` that can be called with the `old` and `new` account and a derivation proof (para-id and derivation-path). This then moves all data from the `old` account to the `new` one.  
The old and new accounts can be calculated just from the para-id and derivation-path but we still pass them in to ensure correctness of usage. The extrinsic can be called by the fellowship or root.

## What Is Migrated?

- Native DOT Balance
- Assets: USDC, USDT, DED, TSN
- Staked balances (unbonding balances are immediately unbonded and bonded amounts will be rebonded and start earning in the next era)

Not migrated would be vested transfers (the accounts have none) or similar.

## Translated Accounts

The translated accounts belong to Stellaswap and are derived from the Moonbeam Sovereign child account:

- Moonbeam Child 2004:  13YMK2eZbf9AyGhewRs6W6QTJvBSM5bxpnTD8WgeDofbg8Q1
	- Index 5: 14vDXpWfcSRPn8eWPKt2Xc8KN57tGNnAo7Z8M2C8kpkJav5q
	- Index 5/1: 1zAWXSCmRTR9ZkRXZXeHZftj1J6rnDe8BLXV8UJ2S2exCvL (**old 1**)
	- Index 5/2: 14KQD8dRoT3q2fCbCC49bFjU1diFu1d516tYuGmSUMmEoGNa  (**old 2**)

- Moonbeam Sibl 2004
	- 13cKp89NgPL56sRoVRpBcjkGZPrk4Vf4tS6ePUD96XhAXozG
	- Index 5: 12gb2DBw5HfpmUyBKCHxJWwGxMyXbUgf6a7bagNduHZC5S9z
	- Index 5/1: 13GWAfgWAKLGm8AsKLn5pDbDyMHfShFgtMFEqM4TRNhXbSea  (**new 1**)
	- Index 5/2: 123oqim7B24XzwB1hC4Fh7LGwbTas3QmxL6v6sVd95eTD5ee  (**new 2**)

The two accounts that will be translated are therefore:
- 1zAWXSCmRTR9ZkRXZXeHZftj1J6rnDe8BLXV8UJ2S2exCvL to 13GWAfgWAKLGm8AsKLn5pDbDyMHfShFgtMFEqM4TRNhXbSea
- 14KQD8dRoT3q2fCbCC49bFjU1diFu1d516tYuGmSUMmEoGNa to 123oqim7B24XzwB1hC4Fh7LGwbTas3QmxL6v6sVd95eTD5ee

You can see the snapshot test doing this here https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/blob/f254eee1fdb071b3d2f5d8cfe6c909b9e156448e/system-parachains/asset-hubs/asset-hub-polkadot/src/remote_tests.rs#L56-L61

pr_details.title: Enable Elastic Scaling and buffered election for Polkadot Hub
pr_details.author: acatangiu
pr_details.body:
This PR configures the AssetHubPolkadot runtime to utilize elastic scaling with 3 cores.

- the runtime is prepared for elastic scaling with expected 2s block times
- 3 cores will be assigned to AHP when/after this runtime change is enacted
- AHP will run with 6s block times until more cores are assigned

The PR also enables buffered export of the validator set to the Relay Chain to handle block time changes from elastic scaling in AHP more gracefully. Without this, era lengths can shrink when multiple cores are used. 

See https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/issues/10142.

pr_details.title: asset-hub-kusama: Prepare ElasticScaling with 3 cores on asset hub kusama and enable buffered election
pr_details.author: lexnv
pr_details.body:
This PR configures the AssetHubKusama runtime to utilize elastic scaling with 3 cores.

- the runtime is prepared for elastic scaling with expected 2s block times
- 3 cores will be assigned to AHK when we have sufficient confidence in testing stacks
- AHK should function similarly with expected 6s block times until cores are assigned

The PR also enables buffered export of the validator set to the Relay Chain to handle block time changes from elastic scaling in KAH more gracefully. Without this, era lengths can shrink when multiple cores are used. 

See https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/issues/10142.

pr_details.title: Implement 'Hard Pressure' Issuance Model
pr_details.author: PolkadotDom
pr_details.body:
With [Ref 1710 - Hard Pressure Capped & Stepped Supply Schedule](https://polkadot.subsquare.io/referenda/1710) having passed, we have here an implementation.

---

The code itself can be reasoned about in roughly 3 parts:
- A general stepped curve, asymptotic to some defined amount by moving a percentage closer to that amount per step.
- The era_payout() usage of this stepped curve.
- New tests for the hard pressure inflation model, as well as some old tests for the previous inflation model that didn't make their way over to the AHM branch.
